Subject:-Nationality of trans-frontier tribesmen under the political control of the Government of India. In reply to your letter No.QllQ/P, dated the 26th September 1924, I am directed to inform you that frontier tribesmen in areas outside British India but on the Indian side of the Durand line are not British subjects unless naturalised as such. In other words, they are not natural born British subjects under section 1 of the British Nationality and Status of Aliens Act, 1914, but aliens within the meaning of section 2 of that Act, and as such are susceptible of naturalisation. Equally they come, unless naturalised, within the definition of n foreigner M inserted in section 1 of the Foreigners Act,1864 by Act III of 1915 and are liable to deportation. But although foreigners for the purposes of municipal law, they are, as British protected persons, in the same position as British subjects from the point of view of international law, and as such are entitled to the recognition and protection accorded to British subjects in foreign countries, they are therefore entitled to receive ! passports.COPY t i m C °' ,y of a le ' tter No. 3633-P.N., dated the 26th nUly 1927, from the Chief Commissioner, N.W.F. Dear Walton^ 1955 ; ALDWYCH, LONDON, W.C.2. 25th September, 1933 In February 1930 an Indian seaman, Amen Sha, applied for a special certificate of nationality. The details were verified in the usual manner by reference to the local Government, and as the man came from Buner we issued a certificate in British protected person form in February 1931. In May of this year he wrote protesting that he was a British subject. We referred the question to the North west Frontier Province for a definite statement as to the man's national status, and were informed in reply that the man belonged to Bagrah in Buner in the Malakand Agency, and that he was a subject of the Wali of swat and a British protected person.
